awd_titl_txt: Alongshore Variable Dune Erosion During Extreme Storms
awd_abstract_narration:
Despite the importance of dunes, there are few concurrent field observations of surf and swash zone waves and currents, and beach and dune morphology during extreme storms. Thus, model simulations usually are calibrated and evaluated by comparison with observed pre- to post-storm changes in topography. The wave and current processes that drive these topographic changes, and the time and space scales of changes during periods of extreme storm activities, are not well understood. The project examines hydrodynamic processes during extreme storms that result in alongshore variable dune erosion over 100-m scales owing to wave collision. The outcomes of the project will improve coastal management, help protect coastal communities, and sustain coastal resources. The project will provide field training to undergraduates, recent graduates, and young professionals embarking on coastal careers by offering 2- to 3-week-long fieldwork-focused internships. This internship program will provide critical experience to participants enhancing the potential job placement in the field of coastal engineering. In addition, a graduate research student will be trained in the use of numerical models for the simulation of nearshore processes. 

Unique observations of surf and swash zone waves, and surf, beach, and dune morphology before, during, and after 3 large storms, combined with numerical model simulations, are used to determine the causes of alongshore variability of dune erosion, over 100-m scales.  The hypotheses examined are: (i) alongshore variable dune erosion and recession rates depend on the initial surf zone bathymetry and associated hydrodynamics, and (2) positive feedbacks between wave runup, reflection, and offshore transport at the dune toe lead to erosional hotspots during storms. The importance during storms of surf-zone bathymetry and hydrodynamics to dune evolution, and the feedbacks between surf- and swash-zone processes and erosional hotspots are examined. The PIs will investigate how waves propagate across the surf zone and beach during extreme storms, and how parameterizations of wave processes used in numerical models may be different during more moderate conditions. Numerical simulations of dune evolution are sensitive to user-selected parameters, as well as to the offshore and surf-zone bathymetry, which often are not well known. Laboratory observations indicate that given best-fit sediment transport coefficients, models may simulate dune changes reasonably well, despite overestimating water levels and underestimating runup fluctuations. The research undertaken as part of this project will determine if the simulated hydrodynamics are accurate throughout extreme storms, and if the time history of simulated sand-level change is correct.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our goal was to understand the processes that result in variable dune erosion over 100 to 1000 m along the shoreline. Despite the importance of dunes, there are few concurrent field observations of surf and swash zone waves and currents, and beach and dune topology during extreme storms. Furthermore, neither the skill of numerical models simulating the rapid morphological changes observed during storms, nor the accuracy of the simulated waves and currents that drive the changes during the storm are known. To address these gaps in knowledge, we used numerical models and observations of surfzone waves, wave runup, and shoreline morphological evolution before, during, and after large storms to investigate the processes that result in alongshore-variable dune erosion owing to wave collision.

The alongshore location and extent of dune erosion was observed during Tropical Storm Hermine and Hurricanes Joaquin, Matthew, and Jose, and the hours that the water level exceeded the dune-toe was used to indicate the expected dune erosion. Areas of predicted erosion agree well with the observed locations of erosion along 500-m of the beach. However, this method consistently overestimates dune erosion along a 500-m-long section of the beach to the south.  Preliminary simulations suggest the differences may be owing to surfzone sand levels. This study formed the basis of a postdoctoral project, and two manuscripts are being prepared. A better understanding of alongshore variable dune erosion is key to improving coastal management and resilience of coastal communities.

Rip currents have been observed and studied for decades. Globally, tens of thousands of people must be rescued from rip currents each year. In addition, rip currents transport suspended sediments, pollutants, fish larvae, and nutrients across the surf zone. Rip currents therefore have the potential to transport large volumes of sediment and to change the nearshore morphology. However, the interactions between the flows and the sand level changes are not understood well.  We conducted numerical simulations and showed that the model reproduces observed flows and changes in sand levels. Furthermore, the simulations suggest that the different initial channel dimensions were the dominant factor controlling the flow and channel evolution in two different rip systems. This study formed the basis of a postdoctoral project, and a manuscript was submitted and another is in preparation.

As noted above, alongshore variations of setup may be important drivers of alongshore variable erosion and feedbacks with surfzone processes. As ocean waves break in shallow water near the shore, they generate a ?roller,? the foamy white bubble-laden air-water mixture at the top of the breaking wave. The water in the roller carries energy and momentum onshore, which affects the magnitude of flows and setup caused by breaking waves. We investigated the roller evolution with a numerical model that includes the breaking-wave air and water mixture. The model simulates breaking waves and water levels observed near a sandbar and shows that the roller transports momentum shoreward and damps wave energy. In addition, the results suggest that the depth of water over the sandbar may affect the shape of the breaking waves, with the roller relatively more important when water is deeper. Other mechanisms, such as turbulence in the water column, friction from the seabed, and the inertia of currents may affect how momentum is distributed in the system. This work is the basis of a PhD dissertation, and a manuscript with these results is being submitted.

An artificial intelligence (AI) based method was developed and shown to reproduce the motions of the water?s edge on the beach accurately. In contract to the fixed instrument, which provides swash measurements along a single transect, the AI method can provide swash estimates along the length of shoreline within a camera field of view. Furthermore, this method of measuring the water movement is relatively inexpensive and easy to implement, and thus may be useful for coastal communities, managers, and practitioners. This work was part of a PhD dissertation, and a manuscript recently was submitted.

The interactions between groundwater and surface water during coastal flooding often result in surface instabilities arising from elevated groundwater pressures. We used a numerical model to examine the effect of groundwater-surface water interactions on the stability of beach surfaces. Results show that after coastal inundation during which water seeps downward into the ground, vertical changes in pressure owing to groundwater flowing back towards the ocean may destabilize the beach surface. The locations most likely to be destabilized are at the toe of dunes that were submerged by the ocean waters and that were tall enough to absorb sufficient water. These results mean that the interactions between groundwater and ocean waves may play a role in the alongshore variability of coastal systems, with important implications for hazard mitigation. This study was part of a postdoctoral research project and has been published in the peer-reviewed literature.
